elements.content: Synthesis and crystal structures of distinctive examples of cage-like silver complexes [Ag6 L 6]·9H2O (1) and [Ag6 L 6(H2O)4]·4H2O (2) (L – = 2-(4H-1,2,4-triazol-4-yl)­ethanesulfonate) are reported. Both undergo solid-state structural transformation to the one-dimensional polymeric complex [AgL] n (3) via a ring-opening process. This transformation is initiated by the release of lattice water molecules and involves opening of nine-membered Ag3N6 rings via bond breaking followed by rearrangement of the Ag+ coordination sphere by formation of new bonds. These structural transformations were studied by thermogravimetric analysis and single-crystal and powder X-ray diffraction methods. Formation of compounds 1, 2, and {[AgL]·1.5 H2O} n (4) with the same Ag+/L – ratio but different crystal structures depends on the concentration and acidity of the reaction mixture. Furthermore, ligand conformation and trz-Ag-trz placement (trans, cis, gauche) are important for the connectivity and formation of the coordination polymers.

elements.content: Cage-like silver complexes [Ag6 L 6]·xH2O (L − = triazolyl ethanesulfonate) undergo ring opening solid-state structural transformation into one-dimensional polymeric chains [AgL] n . During transformation the conformation of the ligand changes from gauche to trans; loss of incorporated water molecules is proposed to initiate the transformation.

elements.content: Solid-state structural transformations involving coordination polymers and supramolecular networks are of great interest for their versatile architectures as well as for their strong relationship between structure and physical properties related to color, magnetism, luminescence, chirality, catalysis, and others due to a change in their coordination number, geometry, and dimensionality. Solid-state structural transformations in metal complexes based on conversion of cis/trans geometrical isomers, or in porous coordination polymers based on guest removal/inclusion without bond cleavage, have been studied extensively. In contrast, examples of solid-state transformations that involve formation and cleavage of covalent or coordinative bonds while maintaining the crystallinity, single-crystal-to-single-crystal transformations are less common, as large changes in unit cell parameters most often lead to breaks in the single crystals and yield polycrystalline powder.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Solid-state structural transformations involving coordination polymers and supramolecular networks are of great interest for their versatile architectures as well as for their strong relationship between structure and physical properties related to color, magnetism, luminescence, chirality, catalysis, and others due to a change in their coordination number, geometry, and dimensionality. Solid-state structural transformations in metal complexes based on conversion of cis/trans geometrical isomers, or in porous coordination polymers based on guest removal/inclusion without bond cleavage, have been studied extensively. In contrast, examples of solid-state transformations that involve formation and cleavage of covalent or coordinative bonds while maintaining the crystallinity, single-crystal-to-single-crystal transformations are less common, as large changes in unit cell parameters most often lead to breaks in the single crystals and yield polycrystalline powder.

elements.content: In coordination polymers, flexible and dynamic structures are most interesting that facilitate solid-state structural transformations. The most common strategy for the synthesis of flexible coordination polymers involves the use of bridging ligands with flexible spacers. Flexible ligands can adopt various conformations via free rotation or bending during the coordination with metal ions or by external stimuli which usually result in structural diversity. Bis­(azole) ligands in which N-donor azole rings, i.e., imidazole, triazole, or tetrazole, are separated by alkyl (CH2) n spacers are a good choice of flexible bridging ligands that have received great interest because of their good coordination abilities to metal ions and promising versatile coordination chemistry. Flexible bis­(triazole) ligands such as 1,2-bis­(1,2,4-triazole-1-yl)­ethane can adopt gauche (angular) or anti (linear) conformations on the basis of relative orientation of CH2 groups. In contrast to bis­(triazole) ligands, triazoles in combination with highly polar functional groups such as sulfonic acid have scarcely been explored so far. With the sulfonate-functionalized triazole ligand (2-(4H-1,2,4-triazol-4-yl)­ethanesulfonate), coordination polymers with divalent metal ions, i.e., Zn2+, Cu2+, Ni2+, Co2+, Fe2+, and Cd2+, have been reported regarding their structural and physical properties including magnetism and photoluminescence. Most of these examples exhibit linear trinuclear triazole-bridged metal complexes, whereas, in contrast, herein we represent the first report on silver complexes that exhibit planar nine-membered cyclic arrangements with three triazole rings coordinating three Ag+ ions in a linear fashion each. This special cyclic structural arrangement with Ag+ ions and sulfonate-functionalized triazole ligands leads to a new type of solid-state structure transformation, to the best of our knowledge not reported so far in the literature. There are several types of structural transformations that are primarily influenced by changes of the metal ion coordination numbers, thermal dissociation/association, condensation, rearrangement of bonds or the removal/exchange of solvent molecules; however, ring-opening solid-state structural transformation from discrete cage-like molecules to a one-dimensional (1D) polymeric chain facilitated by conformational changes of the organic linker is the first example reported herein.

elements.content: In this paper, we present synthesis and structural characterization of four water-soluble silver complexes based on 2-(4H-1,2,4-triazol-4-yl)­ethanesulfonate. The new type of solid-state ring-opening structural transformation from discrete cage-like molecules to a 1D polymeric chain and a plausible mechanism is supported by single-crystal X-ray diffraction, powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns, and thermogravimetric analysis (differential thermal analysis-thermogravimetry-mass spectrometry, DTA-TG-MS).
elements.clean_text: In this paper, we present synthesis and structural characterization of four water-soluble silver complexes based on 2-(4H-1,2,4-triazol-4-yl)ethanesulfonate. The new type of solid-state ring-opening structural transformation from discrete cage-like molecules to a 1D polymeric chain and a plausible mechanism is supported by single-crystal X-ray diffraction, powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns, and thermogravimetric analysis (differential thermal analysis-thermogravimetry-mass spectrometry, DTA-TG-MS).

elements.content: Compounds 1–4 are obtained at room temperature from (Me2NH2)L (L – = 2-(4H-1,2,4-triazol-4-yl)­ethanesulfonate) and Ag+ salts in aqueous solution. Concentration and pH effects were observed in the preparation of these silver complexes. A dilute solution of the mixture of (Me2NH2)L and AgClO4 in a 1:1 ratio at pH = 2 affords [Ag6 L 6]·9H2O (1), whereas at higher concentrations {[AgL]·1.5 H2O} n (4) is formed. [Ag6 L 6(H2O)4]­·4H2O (2) is obtained at pH = 6 of the solution. Compounds 1 and 2 transform into polymeric [AgL] n (3) by a solid-state ring-opening transformation which is characterized by both powder and single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis. Single crystals of 3 were obtained by recrystallization from hot water.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Synthesis

Compounds 1-4 are obtained at room temperature from (Me2NH2)L (L  -  = 2-(4H-1,2,4-triazol-4-yl)ethanesulfonate) and Ag+ salts in aqueous solution. Concentration and pH effects were observed in the preparation of these silver complexes. A dilute solution of the mixture of (Me2NH2)L and AgClO4 in a 1:1 ratio at pH = 2 affords [Ag6 L 6]⋅9H2O (1), whereas at higher concentrations {[AgL]⋅1.5 H2O} n  (4) is formed. [Ag6 L 6(H2O)4]⋅4H2O (2) is obtained at pH = 6 of the solution. Compounds 1 and 2 transform into polymeric [AgL] n  (3) by a solid-state ring-opening transformation which is characterized by both powder and single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis. Single crystals of 3 were obtained by recrystallization from hot water.

elements.content: Crystal structure of [Ag6 L 6]·9H2O (1). Single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that complex 1 crystallizes in space group P1̅ (z = 1) and forms discrete centrosymmetric molecular cages [Ag6 L 6] which are aligned to a neutral 1D system along the a axis via weak intermolecular interactions. Each cage is composed of two Ag3 L 3 units featuring essentially planar nine-membered Ag3N6 rings as the top and bottom faces of the cage (a,b). As in other examples of Ag6 and Cu6 complexes, this structure adopts a staggered mode due to the steric effects with intertriangle Ag···Ag separations in the range of 3.947(1)–4.258(1) Å. In each ring, one Ag+ ion is coordinated in a linear fashion, while the other two are coordinated in a T-shaped geometry with two nitrogen atoms and one oxygen atom of the sulfonate group of a ligand of the other [Ag3 L 3] unit. The triazole groups act as exobidentate bridging ligands. All the (−CH2–CH2–SO3¯) substituents are bent toward the adjacent ring forming a closed cage, although only four of the six sulfonate groups coordinate to the corresponding silver atoms with weak Ag···O coordination bonds of 2.546(3) Å and 2.563(3) Å. The Ag···O separations with the two other sulfonate groups are too long (3.074(4) Å) for a coordination bond. The cages are connected through weak Ag···O interactions (2.606(3) Å, 2.653(3) Å) from the sulfonate oxygen atoms of the adjacent cages to form a 1D chain structure (c). The intercage Ag···Ag distance of 3.416(1) Å is slightly less than the sum of the van der Waals radii for the Ag atoms (3.44 Å), suggesting the existence of weak argentophilic interactions. Furthermore, hydrogen bonds between the noncoordinating water molecules and the oxygen atoms of the sulfonate groups are observed with O···O distances in the range of 2.669(2)–2.871(8) Å. With these hydrogen bonds the neutral chains are connected resulting in an infinite supramolecular structure (d).

Single Crystal Structural Studies

Crystal structure of [Ag6 L 6]⋅9H2O (1). Single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that complex 1 crystallizes in space group P1̅ (z = 1) and forms discrete centrosymmetric molecular cages [Ag6 L 6] which are aligned to a neutral 1D system along the a axis via weak intermolecular interactions. Each cage is composed of two Ag3 L 3 units featuring essentially planar nine-membered Ag3N6 rings as the top and bottom faces of the cage (a,b). As in other examples of Ag6 and Cu6 complexes, this structure adopts a staggered mode due to the steric effects with intertriangle Ag⋅⋅⋅Ag separations in the range of 3.947(1)-4.258(1) Å. In each ring, one Ag+ ion is coordinated in a linear fashion, while the other two are coordinated in a T-shaped geometry with two nitrogen atoms and one oxygen atom of the sulfonate group of a ligand of the other [Ag3 L 3] unit. The triazole groups act as exobidentate bridging ligands. All the (-CH2-CH2-SO3¯) substituents are bent toward the adjacent ring forming a closed cage, although only four of the six sulfonate groups coordinate to the corresponding silver atoms with weak Ag⋅⋅⋅O coordination bonds of 2.546(3) Å and 2.563(3) Å. The Ag⋅⋅⋅O separations with the two other sulfonate groups are too long (3.074(4) Å) for a coordination bond. The cages are connected through weak Ag⋅⋅⋅O interactions (2.606(3) Å, 2.653(3) Å) from the sulfonate oxygen atoms of the adjacent cages to form a 1D chain structure (c). The intercage Ag⋅⋅⋅Ag distance of 3.416(1) Å is slightly less than the sum of the van der Waals radii for the Ag atoms (3.44 Å), suggesting the existence of weak argentophilic interactions. Furthermore, hydrogen bonds between the noncoordinating water molecules and the oxygen atoms of the sulfonate groups are observed with O⋅⋅⋅O distances in the range of 2.669(2)-2.871(8) Å. With these hydrogen bonds the neutral chains are connected resulting in an infinite supramolecular structure (d).

elements.content: Complex 2 crystallizes in space group Pbca with half a formula unit in the asymmetric unit, which, as in 1, consists of an approximately planar nine-membered Ag3N6 ring. The asymmetric units in 1 and 2 are very similar with the exception of one water molecule coordinated to an Ag+ ion in 2. Each centrosymmetric Ag6 L 6 cage is composed of two approximately planar nine-membered Ag3N6 rings, in which the silver centers are located in an equilateral triangle. These discrete supramolecular cages are similar to the secondary building units in complex 1. The Ag···Ag distances in the triangle range from 3.681(1) Å to 3.794(1) Å, while the intertriangle Ag···Ag separations are in the range of 3.779(2)–4.098(1) Å. All these distances are longer than the sum of the van der Waals radii for the Ag atoms. Besides the linear 2-fold coordination of all six Ag+ ions by triazole nitrogen atoms, four Ag+ ions are coordinated by sulfonate oxygen atoms of the adjacent triangular unit. The other two Ag+ ions are coordinated by one water molecule each. In addition, two more water molecules bridge two Ag+ ions of the upper and lower Ag3 L 3 rings, respectively, with weak coordinative interactions (2.741(2) and 2.801(2) Å). With intramolecular hydrogen bonds between the sulfonate groups and the coordinated water molecules (O···O 2.786(3) Å), a closed cage is formed (a,b).
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Structure of [Ag6 L 6(H2O)4]⋅4H2O (2)

Complex 2 crystallizes in space group Pbca with half a formula unit in the asymmetric unit, which, as in 1, consists of an approximately planar nine-membered Ag3N6 ring. The asymmetric units in 1 and 2 are very similar with the exception of one water molecule coordinated to an Ag+ ion in 2. Each centrosymmetric Ag6 L 6 cage is composed of two approximately planar nine-membered Ag3N6 rings, in which the silver centers are located in an equilateral triangle. These discrete supramolecular cages are similar to the secondary building units in complex 1. The Ag⋅⋅⋅Ag distances in the triangle range from 3.681(1) Å to 3.794(1) Å, while the intertriangle Ag⋅⋅⋅Ag separations are in the range of 3.779(2)-4.098(1) Å. All these distances are longer than the sum of the van der Waals radii for the Ag atoms. Besides the linear 2-fold coordination of all six Ag+ ions by triazole nitrogen atoms, four Ag+ ions are coordinated by sulfonate oxygen atoms of the adjacent triangular unit. The other two Ag+ ions are coordinated by one water molecule each. In addition, two more water molecules bridge two Ag+ ions of the upper and lower Ag3 L 3 rings, respectively, with weak coordinative interactions (2.741(2) and 2.801(2) Å). With intramolecular hydrogen bonds between the sulfonate groups and the coordinated water molecules (O⋅⋅⋅O 2.786(3) Å), a closed cage is formed (a,b).

elements.content: Furthermore, intermolecular hydrogen bonds between the water molecules (coordinated and uncoordinated) and the oxygen atoms of the sulfonate groups are observed with O···O distances in the range of 2.762(3)–2.994(4) Å. Supported by hydrogen bonds, the neutral cages are joined together resulting in an infinite three-dimensional (3D) supramolecular structure (c). elements.content: Complex 3 is obtained by solid-state transformation of crystals of complexes 1 and 2. Single crystals suitable for X-ray diffraction were obtained by recrystallization from hot water. 3 crystallizes in the monoclinic space group P21/m (z = 2) adopting a neutral chain structure built by Ag+ ions bridged by triazole groups (a). The silver atom is on the inversion center, while the mirror plane divides the linker into halves. All Ag+ ions are linearly two-coordinate by nitrogen atoms of two different ligands. The triazole group of the ligand acts as a exobidentate bridge, while the sulfonate group remains uncoordinating. The shortest intrachain Ag···Ag distance is 4.227(3) Å.

Crystal Structure of [AgL] n  (3)

Complex 3 is obtained by solid-state transformation of crystals of complexes 1 and 2. Single crystals suitable for X-ray diffraction were obtained by recrystallization from hot water. 3 crystallizes in the monoclinic space group P21/m (z = 2) adopting a neutral chain structure built by Ag+ ions bridged by triazole groups (a). The silver atom is on the inversion center, while the mirror plane divides the linker into halves. All Ag+ ions are linearly two-coordinate by nitrogen atoms of two different ligands. The triazole group of the ligand acts as a exobidentate bridge, while the sulfonate group remains uncoordinating. The shortest intrachain Ag⋅⋅⋅Ag distance is 4.227(3) Å.

elements.content: Compound 4 with the same composition as 1 is formed from solutions with higher concentration. 4 crystallizes in the monoclinic space group C2/c; the asymmetric unit contains two Ag+ ions on special positions (Ag1: inversion center, Ag2: 2-fold axis, ). The crystal structure consists of a neutral framework built by Ag+ ions connected through L¯ ligands. Both of the Ag+ ions are four-coordinate with two triazole nitrogen atoms and two sulfonate oxygen atoms from four different ligands. Whereas Ag1 is in a distorted square planar environment, Ag2 shows a seesaw geometry (Ag2–N2 2.160(2); Ag2–O1 2.771(2) Å). π···π stacking interactions are observed between two triazolyl units with a face-to-face distance of 3.255 Å. The 3D structure of 4 can be described based on the Ag+ ions bridged by triazole units to form 1D [Ag­(trz)] chains along the crystallographic c-axis (b). These chains are connected to a 3D framework by coordination of the metal ions by sulfonate groups of adjacent chains (c). One-dimensional channels (2 × 5 Å) along the c-axis are occupied by solvent water molecules. The calculated solvent accessible pore volume is 11%. Hydrogen bonds between the water molecules and the oxygen atoms of the sulfonate groups are observed in the pores with O···O distances in the range of 2.755(4)–2.922(4) Å.

Both of the Ag+ ions are four-coordinate with two triazole nitrogen atoms and two sulfonate oxygen atoms from four different ligands. Whereas Ag1 is in a distorted square planar environment, Ag2 shows a seesaw geometry (Ag2-N2 2.160(2); Ag2-O1 2.771(2) Å). π⋅⋅⋅π stacking interactions are observed between two triazolyl units with a face-to-face distance of 3.255 Å. The 3D structure of 4 can be described based on the Ag+ ions bridged by triazole units to form 1D [Ag(trz)] chains along the crystallographic c-axis (b). These chains are connected to a 3D framework by coordination of the metal ions by sulfonate groups of adjacent chains (c). One-dimensional channels (2 × 5 Å) along the c-axis are occupied by solvent water molecules. The calculated solvent accessible pore volume is 11%. Hydrogen bonds between the water molecules and the oxygen atoms of the sulfonate groups are observed in the pores with O⋅⋅⋅O distances in the range of 2.755(4)-2.922(4) Å.

elements.content: In the structures of 1–4, two different ligand conformations, anti and gauche, are observed as shown in , with respect to rotation around the C–C bond in the ethylene unit. The ligands exhibit a gauche conformation with torsion angles N–C–C–S of −55.6(5), 52.3(6), and −67.8(5)° in complex 1, similarly, 55.6(3), −75.4(3) and −68.13(2)° in complex 2, resulting in cage-like structures. In contrary, the linkers in the structures of 3 and 4 are in anti conformation with torsions angles of 180 and 178.2(2)°, respectively.

elements.content: The linear 2-fold coordination mode is common in silver-triazole complexes. Possible placements of triazole groups around linearly two-coordinate Ag+ ions are depicted in . The trans and gauche conformations tend to form infinite structures, whereas the cis placement promises coordination forming discrete molecules. Considering the triazole bridging coordination only, all the silver ions in complexes 1–4 are in a linear two-coordinate mode. In 1 and 2, three cis conformational trz-Ag-trz placements lead to nine-membered cyclic structures, whereas in complex 3, the trans conformational trz-Ag-trz placement results in a zigzag polymeric chain structure. In complex 4, trans and distorted cis conformation (dihedral angle 12.6°) are both found alternatingly in the chain structure.

elements.content: The transformations from complexes 1 and 2 to complex 3 occur in the solid state at room temperature accompanied by the loss of crystal lattice water and by a change of luminescence behavior (Figure S1). 1 does not exhibit significant luminescence effects, whereas the solvent free coordination polymer 3 shows a broad luminescence band around 433 nm (λexc = 240 nm), which is very close to the emission maximum of (Me2NH2)L (441 nm).
elements.clean_text:
Solid-State Structure Transformation

The transformations from complexes 1 and 2 to complex 3 occur in the solid state at room temperature accompanied by the loss of crystal lattice water and by a change of luminescence behavior (Figure S1). 1 does not exhibit significant luminescence effects, whereas the solvent free coordination polymer 3 shows a broad luminescence band around 433 nm (λexc = 240 nm), which is very close to the emission maximum of (Me2NH2)L (441 nm).

elements.content: In both, 1 and 2, the cage-like arrangement is formed via an inversion center that transforms the Ag3N6 ring of the top face into the bottom face. In 1 (space group P1̅, z = 1) these cages have the same orientation, and they are arranged in linear chains along the b direction (c) with an intercage Ag···Ag distance of 3.416(1) Å. To other Ag6 L 6 cages the Ag···Ag distances are longer than 6 Å. In contrast, in 2 (Pnma, z = 4) the centrosymmetric Ag6 L 6 cages have basically two different orientations (c). The shortest intercage Ag···Ag distances are 5.7 Å. Although the packing in the crystal structures is different, with respect to the similarity in cage-like structural units, transformations of 1 and 2 into 3 are speculated to proceed via a similar mechanism.

To other Ag6 L 6 cages the Ag⋅⋅⋅Ag distances are longer than 6 Å. In contrast, in 2 (Pnma, z = 4) the centrosymmetric Ag6 L 6 cages have basically two different orientations (c). The shortest intercage Ag⋅⋅⋅Ag distances are 5.7 Å. elements.content: The trz-Ag-trz coordination mode switches from cis to trans fashion following the ring opening. The reformation of an Ag–N bond to the Ag+ ion from the adjacent triangle leads to the new zigzag chain structure (). PXRD measurements were utilized to monitor these transformations (). Single crystals of 1 and 2 were filtered off from their reaction solutions and dried at room temperature for 5 h. For both, 1 and 2, crystals were milled for PXRD measurements. Although samples of 1 and 2 were treated and prepared in the same way, PXRD studies reveal that the structural transformation of 2 occurs faster than that of 1. Crystals of 2 transform instantaneously after separating them from their mother liqueur; the milled sample of 2 shows a diffraction pattern perfectly matching the simulated pattern of 3. In contrast, for sample 1, at low diffraction angles up to 2θ = 25° the diffraction pattern matches that of the simulation based on single crystal structure data of 1, whereas above 2Θ = 25° the diffraction pattern is in close agreement to the simulation based on single crystal structure data of 3. This suggests that the structure transformation started during the PXRD data collection (). Two hours after milling, the pattern of the same sample is in good agreement with the simulated pattern for 3. These observations indicate an influence of crystal packing in 1 and 2 on the rate of structural transformation to 3.

elements.content: During the conversion the linker changes from gauche to anti conformation. As for the conformation of alkanes, the gauche conformation is higher in energy than the anti conformation. This is supposed to be the driving force for the structural transformations of 1 and 2 to 3. Moreover, the lattice water evaporation is speculated to be the trigger of the transformation. During the experiments, we observed that single crystals of 1 can be stable for several days. However, upon grinding the structural transformation takes place very fast. In addition, heating the crystals also speeds up the transformation. The behavior of 1 and 2 is explained by the complex hydrogen bond network between the water molecules and the sulfonate groups which supports the gauche conformation of the linkers. After evaporation of the water molecules, the transformation occurs easily without such constraints. As a consequence, heating and milling speed up the structural transformation.

After evaporation of the water molecules, the transformation occurs easily without such constraints. As a consequence, heating and milling speed up the structural transformation.

elements.content: As complex 2 could not be isolated as a dry product without transformation DTA/TG-MS analyses of complexes 1 and 3 were performed (). For 1, up to 100 °C a mass loss of 1.41% was found, which can be assigned to the loss of one and a half lattice water molecules, indicated by the MS signal m/z = 18. The main amount of water of crystallization in 1 is removed already during sample preparation for TGA. Water detected at 400 °C (by MS) is due to decomposition of the ligand (Figure S3). Above 100 °C the TG curve is similar to that of complex 3. However, there is a significant difference in DTA traces. The DTA curve of 1 shows endo- and exothermic signals in the temperature range of 160–260 °C, which could be corresponding to the Ag–N bonds breaking, trz-Ag-trz placement switching, reformation of Ag–N bonds and recrystallization, respectively. These signals are not observed in the DTA trace of 3. The TG curves indicate the 1D structure of 3 is stable up to 310 °C where the ligand starts to decompose, similar to the thermal analysis of (Me2NH2)L.

elements.content: In summary, 1 and 2 provide interesting examples of solid-state transformations from discrete cage-like molecules to a 1D polymeric chain. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first example where cyclic triangular coordination complexes undergo a ring-opening polymerization process to transform into a coordination polymer. The plausible transformation procedure including coordination bond breaking, rotation of the ligand, and reformation of Ag–N bonds is supported by X-ray diffraction and thermal analysis. In complexes 1–4 two ligand conformations (anti, gauche) are observed and the conversion of them provides the energy for the transformation as the driving force triggered by evaporation of the lattice water molecules. Linear trz-Ag-trz placements with trans and (distorted) cis conformation are found in these structures, which play an important role in determining the dimensionality of coordination polymers from cages to polymeric structures.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In summary, 1 and 2 provide interesting examples of solid-state transformations from discrete cage-like molecules to a 1D polymeric chain. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first example where cyclic triangular coordination complexes undergo a ring-opening polymerization process to transform into a coordination polymer. The plausible transformation procedure including coordination bond breaking, rotation of the ligand, and reformation of Ag-N bonds is supported by X-ray diffraction and thermal analysis. In complexes 1-4 two ligand conformations (anti, gauche) are observed and the conversion of them provides the energy for the transformation as the driving force triggered by evaporation of the lattice water molecules. Linear trz-Ag-trz placements with trans and (distorted) cis conformation are found in these structures, which play an important role in determining the dimensionality of coordination polymers from cages to polymeric structures.

elements.content: Elemental analyses (CHN) were determined on a Vario EL (Elementar Analysesysteme GmbH). The solid-state luminescence spectra were recorded on a F-7000 FL spectrophotometer. The thermoanalytical measurements (TG, DTA) were performed on a Netzsch STA 449 F1 in an inert helium gas atmosphere. The data were collected in the range of 40–600 °C at a heating rate of 10 K·min–1 and were analyzed with the program Thermal Analysis NETZSCH Proteus V.5.0.1.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Elemental analyses (CHN) were determined on a Vario EL (Elementar Analysesysteme GmbH). The solid-state luminescence spectra were recorded on a F-7000 FL spectrophotometer. The thermoanalytical measurements (TG, DTA) were performed on a Netzsch STA 449 F1 in an inert helium gas atmosphere. The data were collected in the range of 40-600 °C at a heating rate of 10 K⋅min-1 and were analyzed with the program Thermal Analysis NETZSCH Proteus V.5.0.1.

elements.content: Data sets for single crystal X-ray structure analysis were measured on IPDS-2T (1–3) or IPDS-1 (4) diffractometers (STOE & Cie GmbH). The single crystals were covered with mineral oil and mounted on a thin glass fiber attached to the goniometer head. The single crystals were cooled down to 180 or 213 K, respectively, to solidify the mineral oil and fix the crystal. The source of radiation was a sealed X-ray tube with a Mo-anode (λMo–Kα = 0.71073 Å, 50 kV, 40 mA) in combination with a graphite monochromator. Unit cell determination, integration, and numerical absorption correction were performed with the program X-Area. The crystal structures were solved by direct methods using SHELXS-97 and refined on F 2 by full-matrix least-squares procedures with SHELXL-2014/7. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically, and the hydrogen atoms were included on idealized positions. The crystal structures are visualized by DIAMOND 3.2.

The single crystals were covered with mineral oil and mounted on a thin glass fiber attached to the goniometer head. The single crystals were cooled down to 180 or 213 K, respectively, to solidify the mineral oil and fix the crystal. The source of radiation was a sealed X-ray tube with a Mo-anode (λMo-Kα = 0.71073 Å, 50 kV, 40 mA) in combination with a graphite monochromator. Unit cell determination, integration, and numerical absorption correction were performed with the program X-Area. The crystal structures were solved by direct methods using SHELXS-97 and refined on F 2 by full-matrix least-squares procedures with SHELXL-2014/7. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically, and the hydrogen atoms were included on idealized positions. The crystal structures are visualized by DIAMOND 3.2.

elements.content: X-ray powder diffraction data was collected on a STADI-P diffractometer (STOE) with Debye–Scherrer geometry. Source of radiation was a sealed X-ray tube with a Cu-anode (λCu–Kα1 = 1.54060 Å, 40 kV, 40 mA). The radiation was monochromatized using a germanium single crystal in 111 orientation. The program Win XPOW was used for data collection and data processing.

elements.content:
The dimethylammonium salt of the ligand, (Me2NH2)L, was prepared by a literature method. All other reagents are commercially available and were used as received.

[Ag<sub>6</sub> <bold>L</bold> <sub>6</sub>]·9H<sub>2</sub>O (<bold>1</bold>)

A solution of (Me2NH2)L (11.6 mg, 0.05 mmol) in 2 mL of water (pH = 2) was added to a solution of AgClO4 (10.4 mg, 0.05 mmol) in 2 mL of water. The resulting solution was allowed to evaporate for 2 days to afford colorless needle-shaped crystals in 70% yield. Anal. Calcd for C24H54N18O27S6Ag6 (1866.43): C, 15.44; H, 2.92; N, 13.51%. Found: C, 15.67; H, 2.98; N, 13.36%.

cln_elements.content: As complex 2 could not be isolated as a dry product without transformation DTA/TG-MS analyses of complexes 1 and 3 were performed (). For 1, up to 100 °C a mass loss of 1.41% was found, which can be assigned to the loss of one and a half lattice water molecules, indicated by the MS signal m/z = 18. The main amount of water of crystallization in 1 is removed already during sample preparation for TGA. Water detected at 400 °C (by MS) is due to decomposition of the ligand (Figure S3). Above 100 °C the TG curve is similar to that of complex 3. However, there is a significant difference in DTA traces. The DTA curve of 1 shows endo- and exothermic signals in the temperature range of 160–260 °C, which could be corresponding to the Ag–N bonds breaking, trz-Ag-trz placement switching, reformation of Ag–N bonds and recrystallization, respectively. These signals are not observed in the DTA trace of 3. The TG curves indicate the 1D structure of 3 is stable up to 310 °C where the ligand starts to decompose, similar to the thermal analysis of (Me2NH2)L.
